html.question: What is the difference between <div> and <span> in HTML?

answers.a: <div> is for text styling while <span> is for layout structure.
answers.b: <div> is a block-level element while <span> is an inline element.
answers.c: <div> is for styling inputs while <span> is for organizing forms.

html.question: What is the purpose of the 'alt' attribute in the tag?

answers.a: To specify the alignment of the image.
answers.c: To provide alternative text for browsers that cannot display the image.

html.question: What does the 'srcset' attribute in the tag do?

answers.a: Defines the size of the image.
answers.b: Specifies multiple URLs for different resolutions of the same image.
answers.c: Sets the source of the image.

html.question: Explain the difference between 'id' and 'class' attributes in HTML.

answers.a: 'id' can only be used once per page, while 'class' can be used multiple times.
answers.b: 'id' is for grouping elements, while 'class' is for individual styling.
answers.c: 'class' is used for styling, while 'id' is used for JavaScript.

html.question: What is the role of the <meta> tag in HTML?

answers.a: To define the character set for the HTML document.
answers.b: To set the background color of the webpage.
answers.c: To specify the primary language of the document.

html.question: What is the purpose of the 'form' attribute in HTML?

answers.a: To define a form that is associated with the element.
answers.b: To link the element with a specific JavaScript function.
answers.c: To set the font size of the element.

html.question: Explain the difference between 'GET' and 'POST' methods in HTML forms.

answers.a: 'GET' sends data in the URL, while 'POST' sends it in the body.
answers.b: 'GET' is faster than 'POST' for large amounts of data.
answers.c: 'GET' is used for retrieving data, while 'POST' is used for sending data.

answers.a: HTML that uses appropriate tags for content structure.

html.question: What are the benefits of using HTML5 over previous versions?

answers.a: Improved support for mobile devices.
answers.b: Support for audio and video playback without plugins.

html.question: What is the purpose of the 'picture' element in HTML5?

answers.a: To provide different versions of an image for different devices or resolutions.

html.question: How do you include external JavaScript in an HTML document?

answers.a: Using the <script> tag with the 'src' attribute.

css.question: What is the CSS Box Model?

answers.a: A model that describes the rectangular boxes generated for elements in the document tree.
answers.b: A framework for creating responsive web designs.
answers.c: A model used for applying styles to a specific box element.

answers.a: Controls the stacking order of elements.
answers.b: Sets the opacity of an element.
answers.c: Defines the border width of an element.

css.question: Explain the difference between 'padding' and 'margin' in CSS.

answers.a: 'Padding' is the space inside an element's border, while 'margin' is the space outside the border.
answers.b: 'Padding' controls text alignment, while 'margin' controls element position.
answers.c: 'Padding' sets the font size, while 'margin' sets the element's width.

css.question: How does the 'display' property affect elements?

answers.a: Controls the layout of elements, such as block, inline, or none.
answers.b: Defines the text color of elements.
answers.c: Sets the background color of elements.

answers.a: A layout module that allows responsive alignment of items in a container.
answers.b: A method for embedding external stylesheets.
answers.c: A tool for creating CSS animations.

css.question: What does the 'position' property do in CSS?

answers.a: Defines how an element is positioned on the page (static, relative, absolute, fixed, or sticky).
answers.b: Controls the visibility of the element.
answers.c: Sets the font style of the element.

css.question: How do you apply styles to elements with a specific class in CSS?

answers.a: Using the '.' prefix before the class name.
answers.b: Using the '::' pseudo-class before the class name.
answers.c: Using the '#' prefix before the class name.

css.question: What are CSS preprocessors, and name one example.

answers.a: Tools that extend CSS with variables, nested rules, and functions. Example: SASS.
answers.b: Browser extensions that optimize CSS performance.
answers.c: Libraries that automatically apply CSS rules.

css.question: What is a CSS Grid Layout?

answers.a: A layout system for creating two-dimensional grid-based layouts.
answers.b: A method for creating responsive images.
answers.c: A system for managing CSS variables.

css.question: How do you create a media query in CSS?

answers.a: Using the '@media' rule to apply styles based on device characteristics.
answers.b: Using the '@font-face' rule to embed custom fonts.
answers.c: Using the '@import' rule to include external stylesheets.

css.question: What is the difference between 'inline' and 'inline-block' display properties?

answers.a: 'inline-block' allows setting width and height, while 'inline' does not.
answers.b: 'inline' allows setting width and height, while 'inline-block' does not.
answers.c: 'inline' creates a new block context, while 'inline-block' does not.

css.question: What does the 'calc()' function do in CSS?

answers.a: It performs calculations to determine CSS property values.
answers.b: It calculates the size of an element based on its content.
answers.c: It computes the color values for elements.

javascript.question: What is the purpose of 'let' in JavaScript?

answers.a: To declare variables with block scope.
answers.b: To declare variables with function scope.

javascript.question: How does 'const' differ from 'let' in JavaScript?

answers.a: 'const' declares a variable that cannot be reassigned, while 'let' allows reassignment.
answers.b: 'const' is used for functions, while 'let' is for variables.
answers.c: 'const' has function scope, while 'let' has block scope.

javascript.question: What is a closure in JavaScript?

answers.a: A function that retains access to variables from its lexical scope.
answers.b: A function that executes immediately upon creation.
answers.c: A method for creating anonymous functions.

javascript.question: How do you handle asynchronous operations in JavaScript?

answers.a: Using Promises and async/await.

javascript.question: What is the purpose of 'this' keyword in JavaScript?

answers.a: To refer to the current object or context in which a function is executing.

javascript.question: Explain the difference between '==' and '===' in JavaScript.

answers.a: '==' compares values for equality with type coercion, while '===' compares values and types without coercion.
answers.b: '==' is for comparing object references, while '===' compares values.
answers.c: '==' is used for string comparison, while '===' is for numbers.

answers.a: Objects that allow inheritance and shared properties between instances.

javascript.question: How do you create a new object in JavaScript?

answers.a: Using the 'new' keyword with a constructor function.

answers.a: A function that executes immediately after its creation.

backend.question: What is the difference between SQL and NoSQL databases?

answers.a: SQL databases are relational and use structured query language, while NoSQL databases are non-relational and use various data models.
answers.b: SQL databases are used for real-time data processing, while NoSQL databases are used for batch processing.
answers.c: SQL databases are file-based, while NoSQL databases are cloud-based.

python.question: What is the difference between 'deep copy' and 'shallow copy' in Python?

answers.a: A deep copy creates a new object and recursively copies all objects found, while a shallow copy only copies the outer object.
answers.b: A deep copy is used for immutable objects, while a shallow copy is for mutable objects.
answers.c: A deep copy performs faster than a shallow copy.
